title: What loan do American‘s prefer？
content:
Most Americans prefer taking out personal loans to consolidate credit debts, make purchases and cover emergencies. The demand for this product has been on the rise in recent years.

The LendingTree in-depth study involved analysis of anonymized data from customers in 2018. It provides great insight into consumer debt and various reasons for borrowing personal loans.

Researchers indicated that Americans with low credit scores often use personal loans to cater for their daily needs. Those with high credit scores leverage these loans for remodeling their homes.

Note：


  • Americans are taking out these loans at an increasing rate, totaling to $125 in outstanding balances.
  • The common reasons for taking loans are debt consolidation and credit balances refinancing. This has led to indebtedness in America.
  •  Many people prefer personal loans, as they are alternatives to payday loans and car title loans.


From the trends in the LendingTree analysis, the majority of the personal loans are meant for consolidating debt and refinancing credit cards. Another reason for taking out these loans is emergencies and other daily expenses. That‘s a clear indication that American people prefer these loans to sort their daily needs so they don‘t fall into poverty.

Further, not every often do people borrow personal loans for home improvement. However, when they do, they take up large sums than what they would if it were a vacation.


LendingTree is aware of the fact that most people with low credit scores prefer personal loans to payday and car title loans. Consumers love shopping around to get loans with favorable terms and the flexible repayment period.

Personal loans are unsecured debt that doesn‘t require any security, such as assets and vehicles, to get them. This has made many Americans borrow personal loans leading to an average personal loan balance of $16,259， a level similar to credit card debt.

According to Experian, over $30000 personal loan balances have risen by 15 percent in the past five years. Worse, it happens after the US hit record levels in consumer debt. This growth has coincided with the explosion of apps and websites which makes it very easy to secure personal loans. It‘s now an easy process to do even from the comfort of your home.

Right now, over 20 million US citizens have borrowed personal loans, which is twice the number of people who had debt in 2012. The senior vice president of consumer lending at TransUnion says that,“ we haven‘t seen major changes like this in the financial services landscape very often.”

Despite the rate of borrowing personal loans, Americans can repay the debt showing how much dedication they are to these loans. They know how important they are in case of an emergency; the need to remodel homes, vacations and many more.

Personal loans always come in handy. However, it‘s important to be vigilant with how you use them. Depending on the need for personal loans, you should ensure that you use them sparingly to avoid unnecessary expenditures as those are monies you will have to pay back.
